text:
JACKLYN PETERSON: And today,
we have doctors Bryant Lin and Oliver Aalami with us.

Bryant Lin is a primary
care physician, educator, and researcher. The cornerstone
of Dr. Lin's work

is keeping medicine
focused on humans-- patients, providers, families,
and trainees-- and not lost in technology
and algorithms.

His research and
educational interests span, one, developing
and testing novel medical technologies,
two, improving

the health of Asian populations
with precision and population health, and three, increasing
expression and interconnections

in the health community with
the humanities and arts. Dr. Lin serves at Stanford
as clinical faculty

in primary care and population
health in the Department of Medicine, where he has
invented and researched

new medical
technologies addressing unmet human-centered needs. And started the
Consultative Medicine Clinic

evaluating patients
with medical mysteries.

Dr. Aalami is a
clinical professor of vascular and endovascular
surgery at Stanford University

and the Palo Alto VA. And serves as the director
of Stanford's Biodesign for Digital Health.

He is the course director for
Biodesign for Digital Health, Building for Digital
Health, and co-founder of the open-source
project, CardinalKit,

developed to support
sensor-based mobile research projects. His primary research focuses
on clinically validating

the sensors in smartphones
and smartwatches in patients with
cardiovascular disease, and translation of
digital health solutions.

Dr. Lin and Dr. Aalami,
thank you for being with us. And I will hand
the controls over to you for your presentation.

OLIVER AALAMI: Thank
you very much, Jacklyn.

It's great to be here. Welcome, everyone. We have quite a few
slides to go through. So I'm just going to run
through here, our disclosures.

So our learning
objectives today, to understand a framework to
evaluate new technologies, articulate value
propositions and limitations

of digital health, and also
appreciate the economic impacts of these new technologies.

I'm going to just start from
the very top and talk about why now, why is it an
interesting time.

And we're basically on an
unsustainable trajectory, currently, with regards
to costs of health care.

The US spends about 17%
of its GDP on health care, and this continues to go
up about 3% to 5% a year.

And you layer on top of that,
despite this crazy spend, that our outcomes aren't that
great compared to other nations

that spend a fraction
of what we spend. Add on top of that, that we have
a silver tsunami or an aging

society. And then you add on top
of that, that we just aren't producing enough
clinicians or providers

to help address or meet the
needs of all these people that

will have chronic conditions. So, the government realizes
this, and for that reason,

any new innovation that comes
out that will be supported needs to meet the triple
aim or quadruple aim.

It really needs to
have better outcomes than what currently exists, at a
lower cost, and to be scalable.

And this just happens to be the
sweet spot for digital health, which we believe or we define
as the convergence of data,

connectivity, and compute power
to increase access and provide personalized healthcare
to improve outcomes

at a lower cost. And this is just a
high-level framework. It all starts with the
patient and data generated

around that patient--
whether it's through a mobile app, an
in-person visit, and a clinic devices, wearable sensors, that
data is then analyzed in a way,

and insights are gathered
from that data, which then feeds back to the whole system.

And healthcare is very,
very, very complicated. It's very different
than the consumer world

when you think about
innovating in this space. You have all these
stakeholders to think about,

whether it's the insurance
companies, the government, CMS.

What's unique about
digital health-- when we do our needs
finding, for example, around this space--
when you think

through the scope
of digital health, you have to include the patient
at home as another stakeholder.

And that's what makes
this field so exciting. And there are certain
enabling changes around data, regulatory,
and reimbursement, as well

as COVID, most recently, that
have really pushed things forward. And I'm just going to touch at
a very high level on what these

have been. It all started in 2009
with the HITECH Act.

The US government,
again, was very aware of this unsustainable
trajectory. And we all have
heard of the adage

that if you can't measure
it, you can't improve it. And so it was very clear that
we had a lot of paper charts.

We didn't have digital charts. And the US government had a
very hard time even knowing where is the spend,
what are the outcomes

like in these various settings. It was hard to measure, so
there was this huge incentive to digitize the
electronic health record.

And there is various
meaningful use stages where it was kind of a carrot
and stick model, where they

were providing funds to
hospitals and clinics to implement electronic
health records. However, they had to
meet certain criteria,

and it started with just
basic implementation, electronic order entry,
drug-drug interactions

for meaningful use stage one. And then it went
to 5% of patients

need to be able to view,
download, and transmit data, which ended up just
becoming the patient portal for meaningful use stage two.

And these are just small
segments of these requirements. But what you're seeing here
are the government mandates

which pushed not only the
digitization, but also now bringing the patient
into the picture,

and realizing that they
needed to make sure that this benefited and that
the patient had the ability

to view this data. It was kind of the
SAP/Oracle moment, that way back in 2009, when--

this really happened in the
1970s in the other industries. And by 2016, about 96% of
the US healthcare system

had certified electronic
health records. However, the government
still realized

that even though the
data was digitized, it was living siloed in these
various institutions or health

systems. And so the next evolution
of meaningful use had to be around,
not only allowing

patients to view their
data through a portal but how can we get
the data to flow outside of the electronic
health records.

So they said that
the data needed to be available or accessible
electronically via an API.

And at that point, they hadn't
quite specified which API, but that was the
beginning of the HL7 FHIR

Standard being
implemented slowly and coming onto the horizon.

And we'll talk about that more. In March of 2020, the 21st
Century Cures Act Final Rule

was passed, and
this is a huge rule. And it has an
information-blocking component

as well, which is
really important. And it mandated the
FHIR standard-based API

to be the API. So now define the
business rules of how data needs to be exchangeable
and how the data should flow.

And then on top
of that, they also mandate that all
elements eventually

need to be exposed via
an API or electronically. And interestingly,
because of COVID, things

were delayed quite a bit in
terms of when it was mandated, but on October
6th of last month,

or October 6th, which is
the last month of this year, is when this finally
came into law.

And it's not being
enforced quite yet. It's not clear how
it's being enforced. You can imagine there's
a lot of pushback,

but this is very
much a reason why

the data is now available
and being made available.

If we talk about
reimbursement, there have been also a
lot of changes which

create an ecosystem
for digital health. Most of the US is still
fee-for-service based,

meaning that you
get incentivized for heads and beds, doing
procedures, keeping the care within the four walls
of the hospital.

And again, the
government realized that this is not really
in line with lowering

costs and preventive health. And the government is one
of the biggest spenders.

They pay approximately
50% of all the health care bills in the United States.

And because of this,
they implemented a lot of quality payment
programs and metrics.

There have been various,
various iterations, whether it's through an ACO. More recently, what's gained
a lot of traction and growth

is the Medicare
Advantage program, which is basically
Medicare managed by other outside insurance
companies such as Optum,

ChenMed, Oak Street
Health, Humana, Kaiser. And they all participate in
Medicare Advantage plans.

And what's unique about this is
that these insurance companies or healthcare delivery
organizations actually go in

at risk for these
patients, meaning they get a bucket of money
at the beginning of the year, and are then challenged to
take care of these patients.

And they're very incentivized
to reach out to patients, implement all the
digital health tools they

can for preventative
measures, telemedicine, whatever it may be. So some other examples of
where digital health has grown

are integrated delivery
networks such as Kaiser. Ochsner Health System is
another nice integrated delivery

network system in the
South and New Orleans. And I believe
personally that they're

one of the most
advanced health care systems with a really advanced
digital health offering.

Currently, they have
anti-hypertension programs, CHF management programs,
diabetes management,

and pregnancy programs. They have something
called an O-Bar, which is kind of like
a genius bar where--

I'll walk you through
a patient's story. For example, if I was diagnosed
with hypertension in Epic,

they put in the order for
me to join this program. I would walk out of the
clinic to one of these O-Bars,

pick up a subsidized
blood pressure cuff. They would connect it with my
phone right there at the O-Bar,

and then I would
get text messages telling me to check my blood
pressure several times a week that would go to Epic.

And a pharmacist would
then review the meds, and based on a protocol,
would send text messages back

to tell me to either go up
or down on my blood pressure medication. And they have solid
data on this showing

that they can get much
better, tighter blood pressure control in much shorter time. So it's a great
success story of how

digital health and
the right setting, with the right incentives,
can really benefit patients.

Self-insured employers are
also very, very interested in digital health programs
Starbucks, for example,

pays more for health
insurance for their employees than they do for coffee beans
to roast all their coffee.

So they also have the freedom to
implement any sort of programs to better manage chronic
conditions or any condition

really that their members have. And it turns out
musculoskeletal conditions

such as lower back
pain, joint pain, is a huge spend for all
these organizations.

And they've, for example,
implemented Hinge Health, which is a remote physical
therapy program to help, again,

navigate patients away
from surgery and more towards physical
therapy, which is shown to be as effective, if
not better or more effective.

And then I wanted to touch
on the regulatory as well. FDA has been very
forward-thinking in terms

of addressing all the AI,
software, or other software,

and will it be regulated,
will it not be regulated. They've put out quite
a few guidelines

that are available online. They also have a website,
the Digital Health Center of Excellence
website, which you can go to.

There's a link posted here. And they're actually very good
at responding to questions.

So if you have any question
about whether your solution is going to be regulated
or not regulated, you can go ahead and
send them an email.

It takes them a
while to respond, but they provide a very
comprehensive response, and I highly recommend
folks to do that if they

have any questions. They also made it very clear
that they will not generally

regulate wellness products. And I'll go into an example
of that in the future, such as Omada.

Omada Health is
basically a program that was delivered to
the YMCA in person--

which was a diabetes prevention
program-- digitized it, added connected scale,
coaching, group sessions

that are remote, as well
as health education. And their program
is not currently

being regulated by
the FDA, so it's considered a general wellness
program, as an example. And then you have
other kind of software.

The Apple Watch itself
isn't a regulated device, however, the software, the
Irregular Rhythm Notification

for AFib is. While other metrics
that have come out, such as the passive walking
speed, passive six-minute

walk test, VO2 max,
or temperature gauge, they've chosen not to go
through FDA clearance.

So just to give you a high-level
view of the complexity of this. And really, in some--

I would say, for this first
section, that what is really

I think a huge insight is that
there's been a lot of clarity from HHS, the Department of
Health and Human Services,

ONC, the Office of the
National Coordinator, that really they
want the patient-- in their view, they
want to drive things

towards a consumer or patient
authorized data exchange. So give the patient the
key to unlock health data.

And if you are an innovator
in this healthcare space, and you would like to
have access to someone

you're trying to serve or
help with your product, that the patient
or your customer has the right to
ask for that data.

And now we have a defined way to
get that data through the FHIR APIs and so on, at
least that's the vision.

So I wanted to just
plug CardinalKit, but we can get into
that a little later. And I'm going to hand it over
to my partner in crime, Dr. Lin.

BRYANT LIN: Great. Thanks so much, Dr. Aalami, for
a fantastic whirlwind overview

of the structural changes
that have been happening and that have encouraged,
and some could argue,

discouraged digital health. I just wanted to zoom
out a little bit. It's hard to have a
discussion about the future,

excuse me, of digital
health without talking about technology and
medicine generally.

Sometimes as technologists,
we always view technology as always a good thing.

And in medicine, it's
a complicated question because we have a principle
among physicians--

our Hippocratic
oath of do no harm. And it's not always clear
that technology is beneficial.

You can see a company
like Intuitive Surgical-- a well-known company.

This is from an article,
an editorial in Nature. One of the Nature magazines.

Just to quote, talks
about how Intuitive is "Loved by
surgeons and patients alike for its ease of use
and faster recovery times.

It's less invasive than
conventional procedures, but the robot's $2 million
price tag and negligible effect

on cancer outcomes
is sparking concern that it's crowding out more
affordable treatments." So not clearly do no harm.

Maybe there are some
benefits, but there are also some concerns as well
about cost and potentially

preventing other
innovation from occurring. And then as a doctor, it's
hard not to talk about Epic.

Dr. Aalami talked about
EMRs a few minutes ago. And there's a lot of resistance
to adopting EMR, initially.

And epic, of course, is the
biggest, most influential EMR

out there. But you can see, sometimes
there are benefits even though it can be
painful to implement.

This was a study looking at
the implementation of an EHR in the critical care setting.

And it didn't affect
length of stay, but did decrease the risk of
mortality, decreased mortality

rates in the ICU. And that was thought to be due
to potentially medication error decreases as well.

So not always good,
not always bad. We need to have a
framework to evaluate technology and medicine, in
particular, digital health.

There are lots of perspectives. In our digital health course,
Dr. Aalami and I really

look at a product
development perspective, and that's the entrepreneur
or corporate perspective.

But there are a lot of
different perspectives out here, just like if
you ever visit the Leaning Tower of Pisa, where are
you in this big crowd

can give you a really
different view of what the Leaning of Tower of Pisa
is and what it looks like,

and how it impacts you. And there's so many stakeholders
in this environment. Dr. Aalami talked about
the seven-headed monster,

eight-headed monster. And lots of different goals
around improving health, but saving money, making money,
curing disease, preventing

disease, many, many goals
around health, in general, and digital health,
in particular.

For example, an entrepreneur
can use this framework.

What do I work on? Do I look at a large
unmet clinical need? Do I look at something that's
scalable, has a pathway,

has a regulatory pathway,
a business model, easy way to distribute
and sell the product?

Do you have any
competitive advantage? Are there other things you
need to prove that it works,

like clinical trials? How to use analytics to show
that your solution is something

that helps outcomes or
helps some sort of goal that you're going after, such
as saving money or making money.

Now, of course, there's a
broad societal framework looking at population health. Can we-- from the government
and from societal point of view,

we want to improve the health
of populations, where we'd love to, of course,
improve the health of individuals,
but looking at it

from a population
health, that can help you marshal resources, how
do you put your money behind certain solutions so
they can help the largest

number of people. Looking at prevention
and management of disease,
value-based care, this

is where the dollars
come into place. And then this new part, which
really, digital health enables,

how do you analyze
this, how do you use traditional research but
also new methods of analysis to show that new
solutions are actually

doing what they intend to do and
not cause them any harm again?

So I wanted to also
just briefly touch on what population health is. So the CDC defines
population health

as bringing significant
health concerns into focus and addressing how those
resources can be allocated

to overcome the problems
that drive poor health conditions in the population. So that's again one
perspective from the CDC.

So you can see how, depending
on your perspective, you may use a
different framework to evaluate technology.

So today, I'd like to go back
to-- as Dr. Aalami talked about-- the Triple
Aim from the IHI.

And the Triple Aim,
again, just to remind you, is focused around
improving patient care, the patient experience of care,
which is around both quality

and satisfaction. Improving the health
of populations and reducing the per
capita cost of health care.

So today, we'll
provide a few cases and talk about how we use
that framework to evaluate

new technologies, new
digital technologies. So we're going to talk
about mental health,

oncology, a couple of cases
of oncology, and as well as-- I didn't include here-- wearables.

Dr. Aalami will talk about case
studies and wearables as well. So digital mental
health, this is really

an incredibly
exciting area, lots of unicorns, billion-dollar
startups in this area

focused mainly
around virtual care, connecting people to
providers and tools. Not quite sure if
they improve outcomes.

It's not clear. Here are some
potential benefits. This is from a
practical perspective,

functional perspective. Notifications, you can
monitor, perhaps track your own mental health. You can share what's
going on, connecting

to a professional,
being part of community. And then having a dashboard,
have a really big overview,

either from the
provider, clinician side, or even from the patient side
about how your care is going.

You can see here they're
just focusing on the therapy aspect of mental health.

Traditional approaches
are in A, looking at acceptance and commitment
therapy, ACT, CBT, PDT.

CBT is cognitive
behavioral therapy, and PDT is
psychodynamic therapy.

And then, of course,
in B, there's traditional treatment,
traditional face-to-face treatment. And digital health, which sort
of the digitization of A and B

as well. So how you convert
these approaches enable them digitally.

So just our case today,
we'll talk about Cerebral. So Cerebral has
been in the news.

You can see from
their website-- this is just a screen capture
from their website. Their tagline is, "Expert help
for your emotional health.

Connecting you with
professionals, basically, at a subscription fee."

This is again from
their website, talking about what their results
are, what their outcomes are.

80% of members have
an initial visit, so great improvement
in access, makes sense.

Decrease in depression symptoms. They don't really talk
about how they track this or what the metric is.

And then significant
impact of large number of people saying their
anxiety is better, so great.

These are-- sounds
like all great things. So what's their business model?

Well, it's really a
monthly subscription fee. You may be able to get insurance
to pay for part of this,

but there's a $30
monthly access fee that is not covered by insurance.

And then you may be
able to get insurance to cover for extra things
as well as medication.

But there's a problem
with this model. Incentives are misaligned. Wall Street Journal had
a series of articles

about how they really had
a great increase in number of patients that
they were managing,

but it seemed like a
significant percentage of these were coming to Cerebral for
access to ADHD medications.

And there were problems
with how Cerebral evaluated these patients. And there are missed
incentives, disincentives, well,

misaligned incentives
for people-- for their providers to
actually provide easy access

because they don't
want to lose customers if they are deemed
not to be needing

these types of
medications, which are controlled medications. And resulted in more bad news.

You can see that they
cut out-- recently, Wall Street Journal reported
they cut 20% of their staff

due to this bad publicity. So these are challenging. This is a company that
did improve access,

seemingly improved
symptoms, but there was a negative side due to
the incentives and conflicts

of interests inherent in the
way the company was structured. So again, let's go
back to our framework.

Improving the patient
experience of care. One could argue that the
satisfaction was improved,

so some people did benefit. You could argue about quality. Wall Street Journal
focused on the case study

where there was one
person under treatment who had a very bad outcome.

So this is unclear, this
first bullet on our framework. Did it improve the
health of populations? Maybe.

Again, depends on
the net benefit. We don't know. We don't really
have enough data. This is all secret to us.

We only know what
they've reported. I don't know that many
peer-reviewed reports

from Cerebral. And then reducing costs. Again, unclear whether
they really reduce costs. There's this additional
monthly fee that's required.

So from a health
equity standpoint, it's not really improving
access unless you're able to pay for it.

Let's move on to oncology. 7wireVentures is a
well-known venture firm in the area of digital health.

Has a great-- And I
encourage you to take a look at their website. --a great overview
of how digital health

is involved in oncology. And this is quite
a broad overview. And you can see, there
are many areas touched,

including care and navigation,
around clinical trials, detection and diagnosis,
research and data management,

and clinical decision support. So really, a lot of
companies in this space. Very popular area.

You can see how different
technologies-- and again, the goal today is not really
to delve into these details,

but you can see how different
technologies can really impact potentially,
possibly, many stakeholders,
and benefit oncology care. Let's focus on this case here.

So this is, I think,
the simplest case of where clearly, digital health
impacted the health of patients

undergoing oncology
care, something called patient-reported, or
e-patient-reported, electronic patient-reported
outcomes systems.

So there are many objectives
for these systems, but we're really going to look
at how this affected patient's

care as part of a
clinical trial but improve the outcomes for patients
who basically self-reported

their symptoms through
electronic digital means. So this is a system
developed out

of Memorial Sloan Kettering. And you can see again, the
details aren't that important,

but patients were able to report
their symptoms that they're having as they underwent
treatment for cancer.

And they, of course, would-- someone who was looking
at this information--

the clinical team-- and was able to
potentially-- the idea is they were able to
intervene early and so improve

the treatment and
accessibility for the patients. And this is looking at Survival.

really advanced technology. And this is really kind of
a workflow intervention.

You're enabling patients
to report their symptoms to their care team.

You can see here,
it's really amazing. You can see the dark line. These are survival curves.

So usual care-- there was a
higher mortality with usual care than in the patient report
symptom monitoring group by--

and the difference
was quite stark.

So this was a seminal
article in the space and led to the American
Society of Clinical Oncologists

to put this in their
guidance documents that this is recommended
for anyone receiving

clinical cancer care. So let's go back
to our framework, talk about improving
patient experience of care.

Clearly, patients
are able to talk about their symptoms
they're undergoing,

seem to improve
quality mortality, improve the health
of populations, decrease mortality. And we don't know
about the costs yet,

so that's something interesting. But these frameworks
are fairly low cost. Didn't seem to require
additional clinical staffing.

So it seems like it checks
all the boxes for us. Let's talk about another
case in oncology.

This is GRAIL Galleri. So this is what's called a
multi-cancer early detection

test. So basically, they're
looking for tumor DNA. And you basically pay.

It's a blood test. It's around a thousand
dollars or so. And they will do tests looking
for the presence or absence

of tumor DNA in your blood. And you can see here-- again,
this is from their website--

around 70% of deaths
are caused by cancers that aren't screened for. So this is part of
the push for how

do we screen for more cancers. We have very few cancers, such
as colon cancer, breast cancer,

cervical cancer, and
some could argue, prostate cancer, that we
actually can screen for.

But most of cancers,
we can't screen for. So this is how they look. They look at cell-free
DNA from cancer cells.

which was published. High specificity, so
99.1% specificity.

But really not great positive
predictive value, so 38%. So if you have a
positive test, what's

the likelihood that
you do have cancer? So less than 50%. And then the negative
predictive value is very good,

but, of course, most people
are not going to have cancer. And you need to screen
189 people in order

to detect one cancer.  And this is from
a different study,

kind of a value-based
study looked at. And you can see that the
MCED plus usual care.

So Galleri plus usual
care, pushed diagnosis to earlier stages, which
presumably, will enable better

treatment and lower mortality. We don't know that yet. And you can look
here, the costs.

Of course, it did
increase costs. Increased costs of screening. And you can see at every
level, it did increase costs

almost across the board except
for stage three and stage four because they're
pushing more people into early-stage detection.

And you can see here,
this is-- again, I won't go into the weeds with
quality-adjusted life years.

But setting the price around
a hundred thousand dollars per quality-adjusted life
years, something a lot

of these studies do. And you can see there's
a tremendous variability. So we don't really,
honestly, have the data to assess this yet.

So because of that-- it's interesting because it's
not reimbursed by insurance,

there's a lot of
false positive risk. If you offer this to every
Medicare beneficiary,

according to Dr. Welch, you
could bankrupt Medicare. So this is of concern. So we really need to
study these technologies

quite well before they're
approved by insurance. Of course, because
of this, we don't

know on a randomized basis-- so the National Health
Service in the UK is studying whether
randomizing people

to Galleri testing
versus usual care,

what the outcomes
are in the long run. And then, of course, presumably,
they'll track costs as well. So that'll be very
interesting, this

randomized controlled study. So, looking at the
framework for Galleri,

it's possibly we're increasing
quality and satisfaction. Hard to say.

False positive risks,
of course, are not something we want as
patients or providers.

Potentially improving the
health of populations. Again, what's the cascade
of false positive diagnosis?

Hard to quantify. And the costs may
increase overall. So unclear on this framework,
whether this type of test

is something that as a
society and fulfilling the Triple Aim, something we
should support, so stay tuned.

I'm going to hand it
back to Dr. Aalami to talk about the
next case study.
OLIVER AALAMI: Perfect. Thank you.

So I was going to get into a
little bit about wearables. Now, Rune Labs is a really
fascinating company.

They're precision
neurology company, and they basically not only
ingest data from imaging

but what's unique about
this 510(k) FDA clearance that they received
recently this year,

their StrivePD
software or ecosystem leverages the Apple Watch
in order to track symptoms.

So something that's really
hard for neurologists is to get that
feedback from patients.

Did the medication adjustment
improve your symptoms or worsen your symptoms? And through this,
StrivePD ecosystem,

they can more objectively
track how the medication is affecting the patient's system.

So here's an example where a
wearable, a consumer wearable, really combined with
some other components

and clinical
factors, was wrapped into this FDA-approved
product by Rune Labs.

So that's a really
interesting case study. And the neurology space,
this is more forward-looking,

but I thought it was
pretty fascinating. Again, a consumer
device, so it's a watch that can detect
atrial fibrillation.

There's a big study that was
just awarded a massive grant. It's going to be a
multi-institutional study led

by Northwestern
in Chicago, where for patients with
atrial fibrillation

who would normally
stay on a blood thinner, an anticoagulant, to
help prevent strokes and so on,

they actually would monitor
the atrial fibrillation because there is a subset
of these patients that go in

and out of atrial fibrillation. So when they have AFib,
the study would then--

the study app would tell
them to take their pill, their blood thinner. And if they don't have
AFib, they wouldn't.

So here's another
just interesting kind of forward-looking study
to see how wearables

could be used and mixed into the
clinical practice or just care.

And again, remember,
digital health is care outside the four walls
of the hospital where most

people live most of their time. We don't spend much time in
the clinics or the hospitals. So that's what makes
this really exciting.

And then this is a really-- I'm surprised Alio doesn't
get more attention. So this is another wearable.

It's a patch with
sensors, multiple sensors, that you put over what's called
an arteriovenous fistula and EV

fistula or AV graft. And this is something that
dialysis patients have and need

for long-term dialysis access. And what's really challenging
with dialysis patients is that their fluid
and electrolyte

shifts are quite dramatic. And they actually
have to report--

when they go to their
dialysis centers, they need to report what were
their potassium levels, what's

their hemoglobin, hematocrit. And this patch, through
artificial intelligence and all the sensors, is
able to provide--

and they received FDA
approval for this-- is able to provide a potassium
prediction, hemoglobin,

hematocrit prediction,
blood count prediction. This can monitor all the vital
signs, oxygen saturation.

And what's another really
interesting thing about Alio is that they not only
provide the patch,

but they've spent a
lot of time thinking about the clinician
portal, how are we going to deliver this
information, number one

And number two, on
the patient side, it's really plug-and-play. So the patient gets this
hub that you see here

on the screen. And that plug, that hub
just automatically syncs

with the device when they're
home or close to the hub. So there's very little
work, or it's very passive.

It doesn't require much on the
patient side, which is huge because we can all dream
up these great ideas

for monitoring, but if
it involves a lot of work on the patient side,
it's really hard

to get significant engagement. So the more passive something
can be, the more likely

you are to be getting
quality data, not to have what we call missing data.

So that is kind of
the summary there. I'm going to give it back to
Dr. Lin to close it out here.

BRYANT LIN: OK,
thanks, Dr. Aalami. So yeah, just to sum it
up, it's already here. We're already in
the digital future.

We'll continue to
evolve, evolve, evolve. We really need to watch out
for misaligned incentives.

So the reason why there's so
much attention in this space is because there's thought
to be a lot of money

at stake, lots of very
valuable companies. So, from a healthcare
perspective, we need to watch for
that and make sure

that the net benefit
is there, looking at the benefits
versus the risks. So there are some unexpected
risks, unpredicted risks,

but there may be some
unexpected benefits, like I would not have expected
Epic to change mortality

among ICU patients. And then lastly, we need to
study these digital health

tools interventions with
traditional technologies, traditional methods,
clinical trials,

but also we need to constantly,
constantly have feedback, constantly have analytics
to show that really we

are not causing harm,
and showing that, hey, how can we do better. The beauty of digital
care is that there

are a lot of incremental
things we can change. It's not like a
surgical device where--

the days are gone where you
can tweak a surgical device and immediately have
that out in the market. There's a lot of
things that you need

to do from a
regulatory standpoint. Digital health is not the case. There are a lot of things
you can do and change

that don't require
regulatory change, and they can be adjusted
on the fly in conjunction

with workflow issues. Thank you for your
attention today. And I hope you will also
check out our class.

And this is really

And with your users' permission,

and I mean, to help

I don't know, Bryant, if

as Bryant said, I have
to have certain processes and procedures in place

that everyone is trained

You can't just buy

I mean, I'll just

postpartum came after 60 days.

And currently, federally
mandated Medicaid coverage is only up to six days.

And because of
this finding, they extended the federally
mandated coverage for Medicaid

for women up to a year. And 40% of births in the
US are under Medicaid.

And most often, those
40%, many of those women would lose their insurance
